awd_titl_txt: Overcoming the Challenges to the Science Education of a Liberal Arts College for Economically Disadvantaged Students
awd_abstract_narration:
The significance of this NSF Scholarships in STEM (S-STEM) project at Stonehill College is its contribution to the success of a larger and more diverse population of STEM students which thereby supports a more effective STEM workforce, particularly in southeastern Massachusetts. The effort targets academically-talented students who face economic and academic barriers to completing their STEM degrees. This S-STEM project is supporting 30 students from two populations: 1) first-year Biology, Chemistry, Physics, Neuroscience, Environmental Science and Biochemistry majors entering their sophomore year and 2) Community College students entering Stonehill as juniors in the same STEM majors.

The scope of the work involves six key recruitment and retention strategies: 1) scholarship support; 2) improved admissions and transfer processes for STEM community college students; 3) early research experiences that provide access to faculty mentors and hands-on research techniques at critical undergraduate moments; 4) enhanced mentoring, tutoring and advising, in particular using a "community of practice" model that allows students to maintain close connections during their time on campus; 5) early exposure to science professionals from similar backgrounds and career preparation; and 6) faculty training through a faculty learning community focused on successful teaching and mentoring of underrepresented students.  This project is serving as a model illustrating how private liberal arts colleges can collaborate with community colleges to improve transfer access and illustrating how financial support, research opportunities, cohort building, career guidance and personal mentoring can assure that underrepresented students graduate with STEM degrees.  Best practices will be shared through local and national professional conferences, publication in educational journals, a workshop and a webinar.

por.por_cntn:
Stonehill College sought to continue its ongoing efforts to assure the success of a larger and more diverse population of students as members of its thriving science community. Because of overwhelming challenges, including financial, social, familiar, medical and disability issues, many academically talented students find it very difficult to reach, let alone to complete college with STEM degrees. This project targeted such students, both those who entered Stonehill as first-year students and those who transferred from community colleges with a goal an 87% STEM degree graduation rate for S-STEM Scholars.

Six key recruitment and retention strategies were employed: 1) increased scholarship support for these two key populations, 2) improved admissions and transfer processes for STEM community college students, 3) early research experiences for students that provide access to faculty mentors and hands-on research techniques at critical moments early in their undergraduate studies, 4) enhanced mentoring, tutoring and advising, in particular using a “community of practice” model that allows students to maintain close connections during their time on campus, 5) early exposure to science professionals from similar backgrounds and career preparation, and 6) faculty training through a faculty learning community focused around successful teaching and mentoring of underrepresented students.

Despite the major disruptions to student academic progress caused by the pandemic, a small increase in the total average annual number of STEM graduates was observed compared to prior to the grant activities.  Small gains were also seen for the graduation of students traditionally underrepresented in STEM and for first generation students. A total of 40 students (7 community college transfers, 22 as first-year students, and 11 as juniors or seniors) were awarded S-STEM scholarships.  Twentynine of the 40 S-STEM scholars participated in grant funded summer research.  In addition to the research opportunity, the major support activities included monthly S-STEM Scholars meetings, a textbook lending library, a mini foodbank (freely-accessible, nutritious, nonperishable food available for students to take as needed), and the opportunity for tutoring in advanced sciences courses. The monthly meetings had a range of programing including faculty members and alumni talking about their career paths, discussions among the Scholars during which the more senior students provided guidance to the newer students, and programs by different campus services.  The STEM graduation rate for students receiving S-STEM scholarships was 92% compared to a 59% STEM graduation rate overall.  The graduation rate for students traditionally underrepresented in STEM was similar to the overall STEM graduation rate (56% versus 59%). Over the six years of the project, 79% of the STEM faculty and 83% of the STEM faculty who taught first-year courses participated in a least one semester of the faculty learning community.

 

Intellectual Merit:

Through the above activities, science faculty gained new knowledge on the impact of using a summer research program as a bridge for community college transfer students and the impact of a faculty learning community focused on successful teaching and mentoring of underrepresented students and on retention of underrepresented science students.

 

Broader Impacts:

The project serves as a model illustrating how a private liberal arts college can collaborate with a community college to improve transfer access and illustrating how financial support, research opportunities, cohort building, career guidance and personal mentoring can assure that underrepresented students graduate with STEM degrees. Stonehill faculty have highlighted their successes through journal articles, and conference presentations and workshops, as well as roundtables and seminars held on campus. The project also provided a larger and more diverse science workforce for southeastern Massachusetts.

 


Last Modified: 09/18/2023
Modified by: Louis J Liotta
